name: biomni-analyze-ddr-network-in-cancer
title: Biomni: Analyze DDR Network In Cancer
description: Analyze DNA Damage Response DDR() network alterations and dependencies in cancer samples. Reconstructs the DDR network from genomic data, identifies disruptions in the network, and analyzes dependencies between DDR pathway components in cancer.
content:
Overview

Analyze DNA Damage Response (DDR) network alterations and dependencies in cancer samples. This tool reconstructs the DDR network from multi-omics data, identifies pathway disruptions through mutations and expression changes, and analyzes synthetic lethal dependencies between DDR components. The DDR is a complex signaling network that maintains genomic stability, and its dysregulation is a fundamental characteristic of cancer cells that can be exploited therapeutically.

Input Parameters

  • expression_data_path (string, required): Path to gene expression data file (typically RNA-seq or microarray data in matrix format)
  • mutation_data_path (string, required): Path to mutation data file (VCF or MAF format containing somatic mutations)
  • output_dir (string, optional): Directory for output files (default: './results')

Biological Use Case

The DNA Damage Response network is critical for cancer development and therapy. This tool enables researchers to:

  • Identify DDR deficiencies: Detect mutations in key DDR genes (e.g., BRCA1/2, ATM, TP53, CHEK2) that create genomic instability and therapeutic vulnerabilities
  • Predict synthetic lethality: Identify synthetic lethal relationships such as PARP inhibitor sensitivity in BRCA-deficient tumors or ATR inhibitor sensitivity in ATM-deficient cancers
  • Stratify patients: Classify tumors based on DDR pathway status to guide treatment selection (e.g., platinum therapy, PARP inhibitors, immunotherapy)
  • Assess therapy resistance: Analyze compensatory DDR pathway activation that may drive resistance to targeted therapies
  • Discover biomarkers: Identify DDR gene expression signatures associated with response to DNA-damaging therapies
  • Study homologous recombination deficiency (HRD): Characterize HRD status which predicts sensitivity to multiple therapeutic approaches

Output

Text file (ddr_network_results.txt) containing comprehensive DDR network analysis including: list of mutated DDR genes with functional impact predictions, altered DDR pathways with statistical significance, pathway dependency scores, potential synthetic lethal interactions, and therapeutic vulnerability predictions.
